detail.content: Dear class:Welcome to the Fall semester of EE 641. I am looking forward to a fantastic term!  Piazza will be our primary mode of contact outside the class this term. You will find the syllabus, schedule, projects, and other handouts on the canvas course website.Piazza link:https://piazza.com/usc/fall2023/ee641Canvas link:https://canvas.usc-ece.com#pin
detail.subject: Welcome to EE 641

detail.content: Dear class,You should (or should shortly) receive an invitation to signup for the canvas website -- https://canvas.usc-ece.com.  Your login is your *USC* email address.  Canvas will prompt you to create a password when registering.  Please confirm that you have access.  If not please ensure you are in fact registered for the course (the roster pulls directly from the university registration system).If you have any trouble with canvas it is best to create a short Piazza post first detailing the issue. That way I can triage the issue and post resolution steps once complete.If you don't receive an invitation email you can sign-up directly:Canvas defaults to a complex random string.  Use the "Forgot password" link to initiate a reset.  Use your USC email address as your login.#pin
detail.subject: Canvas invitation

detail.content: Post code snippets (text) and not screenshots (images). This will make it easier to troubleshoot/reproduce your error.Use a Piazza code block for posting code.Post only the section(s) of the code relevant to your question. Add comments to the code. Note: you should already being this to keep your grader happy.You MUST include specific questions about your code. "My code is not working, fix it!” - is not a good question. Include details about what you tried, what worked, and what didn’t.How to ask a good question?We will post other guidelines here as necessary.Follow-up: ALL, please read (and re-read) the above.  Perhaps the most important Piazza post of the term.Stay active on Piazza! ✌️#pin
detail.subject: Guidelines for code related questions

answers.content:
What NVidia GPU do you have?It should be independent of your editor.  What is important is that you select the correct virtual environment -- assuming you have the corect packages installed.Did you install the proper packages?  I recommend deleting your environment and recreating:# delete prev environment

conda create --name ee641_work python=3.11
conda activate ee641_work

conda install pytorch torchvision torchaudio pytorch-cuda -c pytorch -c nvidia

answers.content: * closed

detail.content: Hello,In function __getitem__, if an image has several anns and bbox, how could we organize the target(bounding-box [list])?should it be a list of list like:[[1, 2, 3, 4],[5, 6, 7, 8]]or just one list like:[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]or some other way to return?Thank you.
detail.subject: HW1 CocoDataset class

answers.content: Which target are you referring to... an individual bounding box (that is, $$0..N$$ targets per-image) or an image?Thecategoryin the datafile provides meta information about each bounding box that you probably wont need.  But you may use it for analysis -- such as accuracy by category --i.e., is machine-printed easier to identify than illegible?

detail.content: Hello All,Is the target supposed to have labels corresponding to each category?As in whether the category is present or not in each annotation? (asking for __getitem__ method)Thank you
detail.subject: HW1

answers.content: No I understood, the annotations file has different segments where each image can have multiple bounding boxes and those bounding boxes can be present at the same location in multiple images.

Don'tdouble-postwith email.  It doubles the work and defeats the purpose of Piazza.  Piazza is the best place to start for HW / coding advice.***> in this assignment according to the annotation file provided, each image> has only - (1) width, (2) filename, (3) set, (4) id, (5) height specified,Do you have the correct data file?  The JSON data file has key “anns” with a very long list (145862 in fact) of annotations:"1134665": {
    "polygon": [
      195.6081081081081,
      147.44303797468353,
      241.01351351351352,
      147.44303797468353,
      241.01351351351352,
      178.22784810126575,
      195.6081081081081,
      178.22784810126575
    ],
    "language": "na",
    "area": 1397.7967841258962,
    "class": "machine printed",
    "image_id": 23096,
    "bbox": [
      195.6081081081081,
      147.44303797468353,
      45.40540540540542,
      30.78481012658223
    ],
    "legibility": "illegible",
    "id": 1134665
  },```> the '__getitem__' method should return image (actual image) and target, here is the> target supposed to have only : (1) image and (2) bounding box (resized coords) as> it's two fields?Per the comments:> # TODO: return image / bounding-box [list] pair for self.imgIds[idx]> # resize the image to conform to your model input and transformed> # bounding box coordinates>> # see COCO_Text helper (i.e., self.ct)> # return image, targetFor more on the collate function (which is complete):https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/data.html#working-with-collate-fn

detail.content: Hello All,I am confused here with this assignment. According to the paper given in the notebook, this Dataset can identify and place bounding boxes around all the regions where text is present and it can also give tags to what it has identified(which are categories) : 1) Machine-printed or Handwritten, 2) Legible or Illegible, 3) English script and non-English script.But in this assignment according to the annotation file provided, each image has only - (1) width, (2) filename, (3) set, (4) id, (5) height specified, does it mean each image has only one part of the image where text is detected/present? (as opposed to what is given in the original paper where it can identify multiple regions/bounding boxes)?Next thing, the '__getitem__' method should return image (actual image) and target, here is the target supposed to have only : (1) image and (2) bounding box (resized coords) as it's two fields? Is this what the '__collate_fn' is also supposed to catch in images and targets?Can someone clarify this part?Thank you
detail.subject: Categories for HW1

answers.content:
collate_fnreturns a 2-element tuple:(images, targets).torch.stackshould do the work of convertingimagestoTensor, so in your training loop:for idx, data in enumerate(dataloader):
  # ...
  data[0].to(device)

detail.content:
Hello,For function:def collate_fn(batch):
    images = []
    targets = []
    for item in batch:
        images.append(item[0])
        targets.append(item[1])
    images = torch.stack(images, 0)
    return images, targetsFor a batch, targets have the type of list. Does this mean when we want to make it ".to(device)", we should use:targets = [t.to(device) for t in targets]Thank you.
detail.subject: HW1 coalate_fn

answers.content: Dont address Piazza questions to me.  The intent is that any can (and should) aide in the answer and asking a question of me discourages that.  And never end your question with "Waiting for your reply", it should be "I will continue to investigate".***From the handout (notebook):# TODO: checkpoint model weights, optimizer state, and other as needed to resume# TODO: plot each of the 4 RCNN loss components vs epoch-numberCheckpoint state and then load to resume.

detail.content: Hello Professor,Is it ok if I train the model for 3/4 epochs and then submit the results? Reason being, google colab is getting disconnected multiple times as it is taking a lot of time to train this model.Waiting for your reply...Thank you
detail.subject: Epochs

detail.subject: Homework submission

answers.content: The grader will check both your output and your code for correctness.evaluate() is your code, validation figures/bounding boxes is your result.

detail.content:
The rubric on canvas has two fields: "evaluate()" and "Validation figures / Bounding boxes" of 4 pts and 8 pts respectively. From what I understood from the instructions, the evaluate method needs to have 4 randomly selected images with true and predicted bounding boxes for 3 different epochs (start, mid, end). Validation errors not required.

Does "Validation figures / Bounding boxes" refer to the "evaluate()" method in this regard? If yes, is there a reason why they're given separately in canvas? If no, what exactly is required of us?

Thanks a lot
detail.subject: Rubric clarification

answers.content: Yes, @26

detail.subject: Sample Exam Papers

answers.content: I think padding needs to be 1 across all blocks, since at the end of each block, maxpooling downsample the feature map from the previous convolution layer to 1/4 of its size. The dimension only matches up with the plot if Same Padding was used.

detail.content: Hello All,I am trying to understand size calculations for CNNs. One of the examples in the slides - VGG16 network :Here, my calculations work correctly if i assume padding to be '1' on both sides for blocks 1,2,3 but for the 4th and 5th block the sizes of the output match only if I take padding to be '0' in this case how do we understand in exam whether we have to take padding to be 0 or 1 (or will it be stated in the question) also normally also why isn't padding size specified in such network diagrams?Please share your understanding on this!Thank you
detail.subject: Doubt in understanding CNNs

detail.content: Dear class:I created the following spreadsheet to organize project groups and assist those still looking for partners(use your @usc.edu email address):EE 641 - Fall 2023 - Project groupsIf you have a group:Reminder: groups should bethreestudents unless I give prior approval.Go to Canvas: "People > Groups".  Choose a UNIQUE group number (i.e., one that no other group is already using) and "Join" the same for each group member (maximum 3 members).  This allows me track students with groups.If you are looking for a group:Fill in the "topic of interest" field on the spreadsheet.  Post to @42 to reach out to specific individuals.  I will also help coordinate students who may have similar interests (monitor @42).Goal: all students are grouped by Monday (23 October) afternoon.
detail.subject: Project groups - Join on canvas

detail.content: Dear class:Feedback from your Fall courses is important. Please take a few moments to complete an evaluation for EE 641 (how-to below). Your feedback is anonymous and is an important signal that describeswhat worked(i.e., the good) andwhat didn't work(i.e., the bad). Even neutral feedback is a useful signal.  These evaluations comprise an important element of the faculty review process so please take time to answer the questions thoughtfully.Your voice matters.I extended the course evaluation window toThursday, 07 December.  It should take only a few minutes.A high response rate is important.  It is essential for unbiased statistical sampling and ensures that reported experiences and outcomes are inclusive.  I set a goal of reaching aresponse rate of 80%(currently, 28%).  I can't/won't assign a bonus for submitting an individual evaluation (obviously, bias and anonymity).  But reaching an 80% response rate would suggest a universally high level of class-engagement that I can incentivize.   So I will include a1.5% class-wide extra creditshould we hit 80% to recognize high-participation and class-engagement this term.Please take this request seriously. Detailed and truthful responses are one of the most important signals that I have to improve or reinforce my teaching as well as EE 641 (e.g., aspects to improve, elements that worked well).   And ultimately to allow me to deliver the very best curriculum that I possibly can. Your comments will be valuable as I plan for future terms.--Dr. FranzkeHow to access the evaluations:You may receive a personalized email if you have not already completed the evaluation, orLogin to Blackboard (https://blackboard.usc.edu).Select "Course Evaluations" from the header menu.Please report back to this post if you have trouble accessing the Evaluation.
detail.subject: [Extra Credit], EE 641 course evaluation response rate (%).
